Description: Fragment of copper alloy strip, with rectangular cross-section, broken at one end and tapering to a point at the other. Bent at right angles to itself about a third of the way along its length. Possibly a fish hook. Corroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A number of barbed fishooks were found at Naukratis, made of iron (Montreal, Redpath Museum 2518.01, 2518.02; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.356; Cambridge, Fitzwilliam Museum E.14a-c.1885; Liverpool, World Museum 9,9,86,126.b, 9,9,86,126.a; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1886.533, AN1886.532; Bolton Museum 1886.31.75.1-d) and copper alloy (British Museum GR1888,0601.7; Bolton 1886.31.73.m; Cairo JE26772.1-2; Montreal, Redpath Museum 2519a; Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1886.535). The naukratis examples are unusually large, when compared to those from marine multiple hooked fishing lines , that are usually only 2 cm long (Thomas 2010; 2011). Thomas,R. I. 2010. Fishing equipment from Myos Hormos and fishing techniques on the Red Sea, in T. Bekker-Nielsen & D. Bernal (eds). Nets and fishing gears in Classical antiquity, Cadiz. Thomas, R. I. 2011. Fishing activity, in D. P. S. Peacock & L. Blue (eds), Myos Hormos - Quseir al-Qadim. Roman and Islamic ports on the Red Sea. Volume 2: Finds from the 1999-2003, Oxford: Archaeopress, BAR International Series 2286, 211-220.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (TB.22) (Phase 3)
